title: Why does AI Hallucinate?
snippet:
Why does AI Hallucinate?
We’ve all experienced this by now. We ask ChatGPT to generate some Swift code, especially using a new framework we haven’t worked with before, and it gives back legitimate-loo...
content:
Why does AI Hallucinate?
We’ve all experienced this by now. We ask ChatGPT to generate some Swift code, especially using a new framework we haven’t worked with before, and it gives back legitimate-looking code. But when we copy and paste the code into our codebase, the function it came up with doesn’t actually exist!
Swift code is just an example, but this can happen for anything. One time, for example, I was planning a road trip and it gave me an amazing destination I was really excited to go to only to find out it’s been closed for years when I looked into booking accommodations.
This phenomenon of AI generating false or misleading information is called Hallucinations. The biggest problem with this is that the AI doesn’t tell you when it’s telling the truth or not. It’s just as confident hallucinating as it is telling legitimate real-world information. So why does this happen?
To understand this, we need to understand how Large Language Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT work under-the-hood.

title: What are Tokens?
snippet:
What are Tokens?
A Large Language Model (LLM) processes text in “tokens”, not characters or words. For example, If you’re interested in using an API like OpenAI to integrate AI functionality into your...
content:
What are Tokens?
A Large Language Model (LLM) processes text in “tokens”, not characters or words. For example, If you’re interested in using an API like OpenAI to integrate AI functionality into your app, you will see that the pricing is based on tokens. For example, here is OpenAI’s pricing model for using GPT-4 Turbo:
See OpenAI Pricing here

You may have also seen AI-related tweets / blog / news about tokens:
Source Tweet

So what exactly are tokens? This is critical to know and understand not just as a terminology and understanding pricing, but for also understanding why certain bugs happen in AI systems.
The best person I’ve seen explain it very very well is an OpenAI founding team member Andrej Karpathy in his video Let's build the GPT Tokenizer. As the video is over 2 hours long, I’ll be summarizing from it here for easy reference. However, I do highly recommend for everyone to watch it…
The Goal
It is much easier to understand tokens if we understand the goal of using tokens.

title: Understanding Large Language Models: Completions vs Chat and Chat Completions
snippet:
Understanding Large Language Models: Completions vs Chat and Chat Completions
Before OpenAI had their big breakout with ChatGPT, they had a Large Language Model (LLM) product and API called “Completio...
content:
Understanding Large Language Models: Completions vs Chat and Chat Completions
Before OpenAI had their big breakout with ChatGPT, they had a Large Language Model (LLM) product and API called “Completions”. The Completions product did exactly what it sounds like. It completed any input. You can still find it and play with it in the OpenAI’s Playground portal:
Here, I simply input “A poem about spring” and it auto-completed the rest of my text with a poem about spring in green.

Most of us are very used to Google’s autocomplete in search results, but what makes this LLM autocomplete so impressive is that it can keep going beyond just a few words. For example, the above screenshot only captures 3 out of 9 full paragraphs it output for me based on my very small input of “A poem about spring”.
If you select the “Full spectrum” in the “Show probabilities” option at the very bottom of the OpenAI’s Playground menu on the right hand side and put in the same prompt, you will see how the LLM model

title: Taming Verbose LLMs: A Guide to Generating Direct Answers
snippet:
Taming Verbose LLMs: A Guide to Generating Direct Answers
Large Language Models (LLMs) in their current form are notorious for being too verbose… For example, when I ask Claude a direct question - suc...
content:
Taming Verbose LLMs: A Guide to Generating Direct Answers
Large Language Models (LLMs) in their current form are notorious for being too verbose… For example, when I ask Claude a direct question - such as “Who was the first US president”, I get this full response instead of the simple “George Washington” answer I was expecting.

This presents a problem for us as developers. We might want to use an LLM for direct responses such as “George Washington” but instead have to work around these big long verbose responses. In this post, we will use one such workaround using the example of an app for generating Swift code in response to a user request:

As seen in the screenshot - the goal is to generating ONLY SWIFT CODE and none of the verbosity around it that is usually present in Claude as seen in this response for the same query:

So how do we approach this?
The first step is to write the system and user prompt with the basic instructions. You can check the LLMManager in the Swift Code Gene

title: Prompt Engineering: Beyond the Hype!
snippet:
Prompt Engineering: Beyond the Hype!
One of the funniest things I find as I’m learning how to work with AI APIs is how important it is to be good at creative writing! If I had a big AI company with lo...
content:
Prompt Engineering: Beyond the Hype!
One of the funniest things I find as I’m learning how to work with AI APIs is how important it is to be good at creative writing! If I had a big AI company with lots of funding, I would for sure be hiring some English / Philosophy majors right now!
Unfortunately, some super sketchy marketing people have started calling themselves “Prompt Engineers”. So just that term gives us the cringe feeling. But it is incredibly important and must-know for working with AIs.
While, as developers, we’re used to working with APIs where we can give very specific parameters, with AI, the interaction is done in natural language. This is much more difficult as there could be many ways and many techniques for getting the results you need. And it could be extremely confusing. As this is something that is extremely new to me, I want to thank @vatsal_manot for teaching what I’ll be sharing in this post.
Thinking in Tokens
But first… before understanding Prompt Engineering,

title: Join Preternatural AI x Swift Workshops
snippet:
Join Preternatural AI x Swift Workshops
At Preternatural, we are working on building exhaustive client-side AI infrastructure for Swift, driven by our mission to empower Apple developers with a specia...
content:
Join Preternatural AI x Swift Workshops
At Preternatural, we are working on building exhaustive client-side AI infrastructure for Swift, driven by our mission to empower Apple developers with a specialized AI toolset. We believe that Apple developers are in a special position to solve previously insurmountable consumer challenges through innovative, AI-integrated user experiences.
As part of our commitment to the Apple developer community, we're excited to announce the launch of our Preternatural AI x Swift workshop series. These workshops are designed to bridge the gap between cutting-edge AI technologies and practical Swift development, enabling developers to create more intelligent, responsive, and user-centric applications.
Our workshops will cover a range of topics, from basic AI integration to advanced techniques, all tailored specifically for the Swift ecosystem. By providing hands-on experience and expert guidance, we aim to accelerate the adoption of AI technologies in iOS, ma

title: Hello, Preternatural!
snippet:
Hello, Preternatural!
You may know me as NatashaTheRobot from my previous blog and newsletter about Swift and Apple Development, my try! Swift conferences around the world, and more. And now I’m excit...
content:
Hello, Preternatural!
You may know me as NatashaTheRobot from my previous blog and newsletter about Swift and Apple Development, my try! Swift conferences around the world, and more. And now I’m excited to bring AI into this mix…
I’ve been fascinating with AI as soon as it “came out”. Of course AI has been part of computer science for decades, but I mean that magical point in time when OpenAI released their breakthrough ChatGPT product that made AI extremely applicable and accessible for everyday use.
As a developer, I immediately wanted to learn and understand it, and more importantly, I saw amazing use-cases for AI in building apps. More specifically, I’ve been studying the Sanskrit language in India for the past few years, and there is an incredible opportunity to use AI to make ancient Sanskrit texts much more accessible for those like me who want to learn. This is just one example. AI just opens up so many opportunities that haven’t been possible before without extreme amounts of

title: Building an AI-powered Poem Generator in Swift
snippet:
Building an AI-powered Poem Generator in Swift
Before Large Language Models (LLMs) became so widely used in the outbreak ChatGPT product, they were actually tested as super powerful completion machine...
content:
Building an AI-powered Poem Generator in Swift
Before Large Language Models (LLMs) became so widely used in the outbreak ChatGPT product, they were actually tested as super powerful completion machines. Based on just a simple prompt such as “And the cow jumped over the moon” for example, the LLM could complete it into a full original poem following in the pattern of the famous "Hey, diddle, diddle," nursery rhyme by Mother Goose. It achieves this by generating the next most likely word (or "token" to be more precise) based on all the training data it has processed, which can be as vast as the entire internet.
However, the LLM’s standalone completion functionality by itself was not found as usable in that state. Instead, OpenAI trained a new model (a brilliant move, in retrospect) with the help of thousands of overseas human workers to apply the completion functionality of the LLM in a User-Assistant conversation format. This chat interface became the breakout product of LLMs.
Knowing t
